stateCorrectness.name: Fraud proofs are in development
stateCorrectness.description: Ultimately, OP stack chains will use interactive fraud proofs to enforce state correctness. This feature is currently in development and the system permits invalid state roots.

risks.text: an invalid state root is submitted to the system.

references.text: L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, deleteL2Outputs function

dataAvailability.name: Data required to compute fraud proofs is published offchain without onchain attestations
dataAvailability.description: Xterio relies on DA challenges for data availability. If a DA challenger finds that the data behind a tx data commitment is not available, they can submit a challenge which requires locking a bond within 12h. A challenge can be resolved by publishing the preimage data within an additional 12h. In such a case, a portion of the challenger bond is burned, with the exact amount estimated as the cost incurred by the resolver to publish the full data, meaning that the resolver and challenger will approximately lose the same amount of funds. The system is not secure if the malicious sequencer is able to outspend the altruistic challengers. If instead, after a challenge, the preimage data is not published, the chain reorgs to the last fully derivable state.

references.text: Universal Plasma and DA Challenges - Ethresear.ch
Derivation: Batch submission - OP Mainnet specs
OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, depositTransaction function

risks.text: the sequencer is malicious and is able to economically outspend the altruistic challengers.
there is no challenger willing to challenge unavailable data commitments.

operator.name: The system has a centralized operator
operator.description: The operator is the only entity that can propose blocks. A live and trustworthy operator is vital to the health of the system.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

references.text: L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, CHALLENGER address
L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, PROPOSER address

forceTransactions.name: Users can force any transaction
forceTransactions.description: Because the state of the system is based on transactions submitted on the underlying host chain and anyone can submit their transactions there it allows the users to circumvent censorship by interacting with the smart contract on the host chain directly.

references.text: OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, depositTransaction function

exitMechanisms.name: Regular exit
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates the withdrawal by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is finalized the funds become available for withdrawal on L1. The process of block finalization takes a challenge period of 7d to complete. Finally the user submits an L1 transaction to claim the funds. This transaction requires a merkle proof.

risks.text: the centralized validator goes down. Users cannot produce blocks themselves and exiting the system requires new block production.

references.text: OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, proveWithdrawalTransaction function
OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, finalizeWithdrawalTransaction function
L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, PROPOSER check

exitMechanisms.name: Forced exit
exitMechanisms.description: If the user experiences censorship from the operator with regular exit they can submit their withdrawal requests directly on L1. The system is then obliged to service this request or halt all withdrawals, including forced withdrawals from L1 and regular withdrawals initiated on L2. Once the force operation is submitted and if the request is serviced, the operation follows the flow of a regular exit.

references.text: Forced withdrawal from an OP Stack blockchain

otherConsiderations.name: EVM compatible smart contracts are supported
otherConsiderations.description: OP stack chains are pursuing the EVM Equivalence model. No changes to smart contracts are required regardless of the language they are written in, i.e. anything deployed on L1 can be deployed on L2.

permissions.name: ProxyAdmin
permissions.description: Owner of AddressManager. Admin of OptimismPortal, SystemConfig, L2OutputOracle, L1ERC721Bridge, OptimismMintableERC20Factory, L1StandardBridge.

permissions.name: Sequencer
permissions.description: Central actor allowed to commit L2 transactions to L1.

permissions.name: Proposer
permissions.description: Central actor allowed to post new L2 state roots to L1.

permissions.name: Challenger
permissions.description: Central actor allowed to delete L2 state roots proposed by a Proposer.

permissions.name: Guardian
permissions.description: Central actor allowed to pause deposits and withdrawals.

permissions.name: RollupOwnerMultisig
permissions.description: This is a Gnosis Safe with 3 / 4 threshold.  Owner of the ProxyAdmin and the rollup system. It can upgrade the bridge implementation potentially gaining access to all funds, and change any system component.

permissions.name: DataAvailabilityChallenge owner
permissions.description: Owner of the DataAvailabilityChallenge contract. It can upgrade the contract params, potentially making the system insecure.

permissions.name: SystemConfig owner
permissions.description: Account privileged to change System Config parameters such as Sequencer Address and gas limit.

addresses.name: L2OutputOracle
addresses.description: The L2OutputOracle contract contains a list of proposed state roots which Proposers assert to be a result of block execution. Currently only the PROPOSER address can submit new state roots.

addresses.name: OptimismPortal
addresses.description: The OptimismPortal contract is the main entry point to deposit funds from L1 to L2. It also allows to prove and finalize withdrawals.

addresses.name: SystemConfig
addresses.description: It contains configuration parameters such as the Sequencer address, the L2 gas limit and the unsafe block signer address.

addresses.name: L1CrossDomainMessenger
addresses.description: The L1CrossDomainMessenger (L1xDM) contract sends messages from L1 to L2, and relays messages from L2 onto L1. In the event that a message sent from L1 to L2 is rejected for exceeding the L2 epoch gas limit, it can be resubmitted via this contract's replay function.

addresses.name: L1StandardBridge
addresses.description: The L1StandardBridge contract is the main entry point to deposit ERC20 tokens from L1 to L2.

addresses.name: L1ERC721Bridge
addresses.description: The L1ERC721Bridge contract is used to bridge ERC-721 tokens from L1 to L2.

addresses.name: DataAvailabilityChallenge
addresses.description: The DataAvailabilityChallenge contract is used to challenge the data availability of tx data hashes. See the technology section for more details.

addresses.name: SuperchainConfig
addresses.description: Upgradable contract that manages the PAUSED_SLOT, a boolean value indicating whether the Superchain is paused, and GUARDIAN_SLOT, the address of the guardian which can pause and unpause the system. The address of the guardian can only be modified by the ProxyAdmin by upgrading the SuperchainConfig contract. This contract is a fork of Optimism's superchainConfig contract and is unrelated to the one used by the OP stack Superchain.

risks.text: a contract receives a malicious code upgrade. There is no delay on code upgrades.

display.name: Xterio Chain
display.description: Xterio Chain is an OP stack Optimium on Ethereum. The chain focuses on gaming, high performance and low fees .
display.warning: Fraud proof system is currently under development. Users need to trust the block proposer to submit correct L1 state roots.

contract.description: Main entry point for users depositing ETH.
Main entry point for users depositing ERC20 token that do not require custom gateway.

layer.description: The data is posted to XterioDA which is a separate data availability module developed by the Xterio team. Data is posted off chain, and only hashes of data are published on an on chain inbox.

bridge.description: There is no bridge that can attest if the data has been made available. However, there is a mechanism that allows users to challenge unavailability of data.

stateValidation.description: Currently the system permits invalid state roots. More details in project overview.

dataAvailability.description: Proof construction and state derivation rely on data that is NOT published onchain. Xterio uses a custom data availability provider without attestations, relying though on DA challenges.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

sequencerFailure.description: In the event of a sequencer failure, users can force transactions to be included in the project's chain by sending them to L1. There is a 12h delay on this operation.

proposerFailure.description: Only the whitelisted proposers can publish state roots on L1, so in the event of failure the withdrawals are frozen.

destinationToken.description: ETH transferred via this bridge is used to pay for gas and other tokens transferred are considered canonical on the destination chain.

validatedBy.description: Smart contracts on Ethereum validate all bridge transfers.
